Things will get even worse in states with high maternal mortality, inadequate reproductive health care access

"States with the highest maternal mortality rates and the worst pregnancy care access are the same ones that will ban abortion."
–Carolyn Sufrin, @HopkinsMedicine (4/4)

Anticipating a ruling from the U.S. Supreme Court that could overturn laws protecting abortion rights, Johns Hopkins experts discuss a potential future without these safeguards. (1/4)
https://t.co/XpRmQU3hQh

Profound effects beyond ending access to a routine procedure

"Forced childbearing makes it more difficult for vulnerable people to escape situations of abuse, domestic violence, duress, and economic hardship."
–@eobrie19, Assistant Professor, History of Medicine (3/4)

Women without privilege will be criminalized

"Women who travel regularly may be able to hide the purpose of an abortion trip. Not so much for an undocumented woman who struggles to find the gas money to cross state lines."
–@mary_fissell, professor, History of Medicine (2/4)

Scientists at @JohnsHopkins and @ScrippsResearch have characterized 30 #antibodies that recognize a wide range of coronaviruses—successfully blocking not only all the SARS-CoV-2 #variants that were tested, but also other related viruses. https://t.co/fFXserDfQC

Between labor shortages, supply chain disruptions, and energy market chaos, it's hard to predict where the U.S. economy is heading.

JHU economist Laurence Ball explains what factors influence rising inflation and what could trigger a recession: https://t.co/DUF8pMCknE

"There's a number of reforms we need, and they often act in tandem," explains @JoshuaMHorwitz of @JHU_CGVS.

"There's nothing that we potentially can do that would solve all of this, but we can just do so much better than we're doing right now."
https://t.co/H580YH79RW

"Making predictions beyond the next few months is not feasible," says @T_Inglesby of @JHSPH_CHS.

Neuroscientists at @JHUArtsSciences say understanding the hippocampus and its function may be the key to preventing cognitive decline.

Today's discussion will cover:
- The challenge gun violence poses for American democracy
- Effective gun laws
- How Extreme Risk Protection Orders can help prevent gun violence

A new @HopkinsMedicine study of 8,000 racially diverse women added to evidence that following a Mediterranean-style diet could lower the risk of #preeclampsia, a blood pressure disorder in pregnancy, by at least 20%: https://t.co/yjjfG7NmN2

(8/9) There are policies that work to prevent gun violence—if we deploy them

"Public health means prevention, and our center (@JHU_CGVS) will continue to educate policymakers and the public about preventive measures to curb this epidemic." –@lisabgeller

(9/9) Tune in tomorrow, June 2, at 10 a.m. EDT for a live virtual briefing in which Johns Hopkins experts will discuss solutions to gun violence in the U.S. and answer questions from viewers:
https://t.co/Lns5WqBdNI

(6/9) Leaders who fail to act are culpable

"As a parent, the news hits closer to home...I cannot imagine the anguish of the families who lost their loved ones. As a professional working on federal policy to prevent gun violence, I am frustrated by the inaction." –@SpenceCantrell

(7/9) Turn heartache into action

"When I lose a patient to gun violence, there is a special heartache that is mixed with rage because I know there is so much that medicine & public health have to offer that wasn't done to prevent the loss of that precious life." –@KatherineHoops

(5/9) Ensure school buildings are secure

"One conversation to emerge from this tragic period is to consider how we can make small yet consequential building upgrades to school doors so that every child can be safe and healthy in school."
–@ImpactGreater

(3/9) More police in schools doesn't solve the problem of easy access to guns

"Knee-jerk school police policies have not ended school shootings, and may have undermined achievement in U.S. schools."
–@NEqualityMatrix

(4/9) Focus on humiliation in schools as a driver of withdrawal, confrontation, and violence

"All students have a fundamental right to participate in their school and community free from degradation."
–Sheldon Greenberg, @JHUEducation

🧵 (1/9): How can we stop gun violence in America?

Experts from across Johns Hopkins share their thoughts on how the U.S. can address what seems to be a uniquely American problem:
https://t.co/btoFQ3JJf1

(2/9) Make it harder to turn violent thoughts into violence

"America suffers more shootings because it is so much easier for even fleeting violent thoughts here to be immediately translated into deadly action thanks to easy access to military grade weaponry."
–@paulnestadt

Discussion will cover:
- The challenge gun violence poses for American democracy

@C_R_Watson @JHSPH_CHS @biblauer "We cannot afford to become numb to these numbers," says @IVACtweets director Bill Moss.

"We must continue to strive to achieve higher vaccination coverage with COVID-19 vaccines both here in the U.S. and globally to avert an even greater disaster." https://t.co/175QuLNZmq

@C_R_Watson @JHSPH_CHS @biblauer "Vaccines and boosters dramatically reduce the risk of developing severe disease and have really changed the game by reducing the number of patients who require ICU-level care," says Brian Garibaldi, medical director  of the Johns Hopkins Biocontainment Unit.

@C_R_Watson @JHSPH_CHS The tragedy is compounded by the realization that far more have perished, says @biblauer.

"[U.S.] data reporting and tracking systems are so flawed that local, state, and federal agencies have not been able to provide with full confidence just how deadly this pandemic has been."

"The shock of so many deaths, along with the large number of people now living with long-COVID symptoms, means that this pandemic will unfortunately be felt by individuals, and reflected in our public health data, for a long time to come," said @C_R_Watson of @JHSPH_CHS.

The U.S. has surpassed one million COVID-19 deaths.

The tragic milestone, recorded today by our Coronavirus Resource Center tracker, likely occurred months ago, and higher vaccination rates could have prevented many fatalities, according to JHU experts.

Currently, people at risk for #lymphedema can only be tested at clinics or hospitals.

Johns Hopkins grad students have created a sensor that would allow patients to test their fluid levels at home, in about as much time as it takes to brush their teeth.
https://t.co/P7viaJmAtF

This new sensor is nearly as sensitive as a PCR test and as convenient as a rapid antigen test.

The technology has the potential to eventually be integrated with hand-held testing devices and wearables.
https://t.co/WEjiJ2kZE8

Millions of people use the NYC subway system each day, often for just a few stops. One JHU student decided to see how quickly he could navigate the entire 300-mile system.
